questions.text:
Match the following skin lesions with their most suitable clinical descriptions.
  1. Polycyclic
  2. Arcuate
  3. Nummular
  4. Annular
questions.solution:
The correct match is option A: 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Image 1 shows a psoriatic plaque which is shaped as a filled circular lesion. This is known as nummular shape.

 

Image 2 depicts annular lesions which can be described as open circles with different central skin when compared to the rim. It is seen in tinea corporis and granuloma annulare.

Image 3 shows arcuate lesions which are incomplete circular lesions, seen in urticaria.

Image 4 shows chronic plaque psoriasis and is best described as polycyclic.

Well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with silvery scales characteristic of chronic plaque psoriasis. Polycyclic skin lesions are present as circles that have merged together. In severe cases of psoriasis, plaques grow and merge into one another forming polycyclic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a secondary skin lesion?
questions.solution:

Other options:

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is unlikely to present with skin lesions on the shin?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is unlikely to present with skin lesions on shin. Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) and pretibial myxedema are different entities. Pretibial myxedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin in Grave's disease, a type of hyperthyroidism. 

Other options :

Option B: Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is classically seen on the anterior leg.

Option A: Sarcoidosis: Erythema nodosum may be seen on the anterior leg.

questions.text: The following skin lesion is caused by ___________

choices.text: Hypersensitivity to Herpes Simplex virus infection

questions.solution:
The image shows numerous concentric rings indicative of Tinea imbricata, resulting from infection by Trichophyton concentricum.

The lesion presents as a scaling ring; centrifugal spread follows, but within the area of central clearing a second wave of scaling soon arises. The process is repeated to give numerous concentric rings. Pruritus is intense and may lead to lichenification. Hypopigmentation may accompany the lesions. It is restricted to the natives of southern Asia, the islands of the South Pacific, Guatemala, southern Mexico and Brazil.

questions.text: Migratory necrolytic skin rash is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Glucagonoma, a neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas presents with migratory necrolytic skin rash.

Glucagonoma is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis(positive Homan’s sign and Moses Sign is suggestive of DVT), and depression.

Necrolytic migrating erythema/skin rash is a characteristic skin lesion seen in glucagonoma patients usually before the appearance of other symptoms It is thought to be caused by low levels of amino acids. Therefore parenteral administration of amino acids was found to result in the disappearance of the skin lesions.

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of > 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a skin lesion that is red, edematous, and well-demarcated from the surrounding skin. These features are suggestive of erysipelas. 

Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by streptococcus. It presents as erythematous, indurated, and inflamed skin lesions.

Other options:

Option B: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by the exfoliative toxin and presents with peeling of the affected skin.

Option C: Necrotizing fasciitis is a streptococcal infection involving the fascial planes. The lesions show dark areas of necrosis along with erythema.

Option D: Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis. It is a bacterial infection in which tissue gas is produced in gangrene. It is usually caused by Clostridium perfringens. The given image of gas gangrene shows necrotic bullae, erythema, and edema:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your OPD with lesions as shown below. The parent says he also had similar lesions in childhood. The lesions are present on the forearm, face, and flexures and are very itchy on the background of dry skin showing signs of lichenification. Grattage test or scratching reveals oozing of serous fluid. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image showing eczematous lesions on the forearm, and flexures. This along with the history of them being very itchy and being located on the dry skin showing signs of lichenification and a grattage test revealing oozing of serous fluid points towards atopic dermatitis as the likely diagnosis.

Atopic dermatitis can be divided into 3 phases: Infantile, childhood, and adult phases.

Infantile phase: The lesions of Atopic Eczema most frequently start on the face but may occur anywhere on the skin surface. Often, the napkin area is relatively spared.

  • When the child begins to crawl, the exposed surfaces, especially the extensor aspect of the knees and elbows are most involved.
  • The lesions consist of erythema and discrete or confluent oedematous papules. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.
  • Secondary infection and lymphadenopathy are common.

Childhood Phase: From 18 to 24 months onwards, the sites most characteristically involved are the elbow and knee flexures, a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper‐ and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification may be seen depending on the skin type on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles.

  • The sides of the neck may show a striking reticulate pigmentation, sometimes referred to as atopic dirty neck.
  • The erythematous and oedematous papules tend to be replaced by lichenification.

Adult Phase: The picture is essentially similar to that in later childhood, with lichenification, especially of the flexures and hands.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen simplex chronicus usually presents as an itchy plaque. Chronic itching produces secondary lichenification. It may be associated with the history of atopy. It is less likely to appear as oozing on scratching. A predilection for flexural aspect in childhood as in this case is not classically seen.

Option B: Psoriasis classically involves extensor aspect unlike flexures as in this child. Moreover, it is associated with silvery scaling and grattage reveals fresh bleeding points (Auspitz sign) and not oozing of serous fluid.

Option D: Scabies is caused by itch mites laying eggs in burrows made in the skin. The burrows are visible as serpiginous erythematous lesions. It classically causes itching more during the evening and involves lesions in the circle of hebra unlike flexures as in this case.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as depicted below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is kwashiorkor. The above clinical vignette and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are seen characteristically in kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is the peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

questions.text: Identify the skin lesions shown in the image below.

choices.text: A- Shingles, B-Molluscum contagiosum, C- Herpangina, D- Cutaneous larva migrans
A- Cutaneous larva migrans, B- Folliculitis, C- Molluscum contagiosum, D-Herpangina
A- Molluscum contagiosum, B- Herpangina, C- Cutaneous larva migrans, D- Folliculitis
A- Folliculitis, B-Shingles, C- Molluscum contagiosum, D- Cutaneous larva migrans

questions.solution:
The correct match is A- Shingles, B-Molluscum contagiosum, C- Herpangina, D- Cutaneous larva migrans.

Shingles or herpes zoster consist of red papules, which later become vesicular and pustular. They are dermatomal in distribution.

Below Image- Shingles

The lesions of the molluscum contagiosum are shiny, white, and hemispherical. It is umbilicated with a central pore. It is caused by poxvirus.

Below image- Molluscum contagiosum

Herpangina presents as 15-20 tiny vesicles with red areola on the pharynx, tonsils, uvula, and soft palate. It is caused by coxsackie viruses.

Below image- Herpangina

Cutaneous larva migrans show raised, flesh, or pink-colored lesions with serpentine borders. It is commonly caused by Ancylostoma brasiliense, Ancylostoma caninum, Ancylostoma ceylonicum, etc.

Below image- Cutaneous larva migrans

questions.text: A patient presents with itching around the periorbital region. Identify the given skin lesion?
questions.solution:
This given image is of Lichen Planus dermatitis of the face.

Typically the lesion shows firm, shiny, polygonal, papules with a red to violet color. On closer observation, tracers of thin white lines can be seen on the surface of the lesions (Wickham’s striae).

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Shown below is a skin lesion. Which of the following is not a criterion to assess its malignant potential?
questions.solution:
The image shown above depicts a nevus. Diameter >6 mm is the diagnostic clue for the transformation of a nevus to a melanoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy developed skin lesions on his trunk and proximal portion of his arms, 10 days after he recovered from an episode of pharyngitis. The skin lesions are shown in the image below. Which among the following are correct about this condition?
  1. It follows a chronic course
  2. It is associated with HLA‐C:06:02
  3. It responds to broadband UVB phototherapy
  4. May lead to toxicity and hypocalcemia
  5. Acitretin is the drug of choice
questions.solution:
The clinical stem of small, red, drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (shown in the image) after an attack of pharyngitis is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis, and statements 2 and 3 are correct.

Guttate psoriasis is a type of psoriasis occurring as a sudden onset shower of small lesions seen diffusely over the body, more on the trunk and proximal limbs. It is more common in children and young adults, following infection with group A streptococcus and is often the first presentation of psoriasis. It can also occur as a flare-up in adults with plaque psoriasis that began in childhood. It is linked to HLA‐C:06:02 (statement 2).

Lesions usually resolve over about 3 months. Some patients with acute guttate psoriasis might develop plaque psoriasis in the future.

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials: Recurrent episodes may be related to the pharyngeal carriage of the responsible streptococcus by the patient or close contact. A course of a semisynthetic penicillin (Eg dicloxacillin) with rifampin may be required to clear chronic streptococcal carriage.
  • Phototherapy: Broad-band ultraviolet B (UVB): Response is better with broadband UVB (statement 3) over narrow-band UVB. 

Other options:

Statement 1: Plaque psoriasis and follicular psoriasis follow a chronic course.

Statements 4 and 5 are true about pustular psoriasis, where the patient is often ill with fever, erythroderma, hypocalcemia, and cachexia, for which Acetretin is the drug of choice.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following skin lesions. Identify the virus causing these lesions.
questions.solution:
The above image showing red-purple macules and plaques in an HIV-positive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, and is caused by the human herpes virus 8 (otherwise known as Kaposi Sarcoma-associated Herpes Virus (KSHV) ).

The sarcoma is a soft tissue carcinoma characterized by red papules and has a vascular origin. There are two forms of Kaposi sarcoma namely the sporadic form and the HIV-associated form. The latter form is more aggressive and involves the skin, gastrointestinal tract, and mucous membranes. The lesions are widespread and progressive in nature. They contain spindle cells that promote pro-inflammatory factors leading to the occurrence of malignancy. 

HHV8 virus infiltrates B lymphocytes, macrophages, epithelial, and endothelial cells predisposing the patient to a number of malignancies. KSHV is a known causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma
  2. KSHV-associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD)
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma
  4. KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome 

It is one of the seven currently known human cancer viruses or oncoviruses. The other oncoviruses include HBV (Hepatitis B virus), HTLV (Human T lymphotrophic virus), HCV (Hepatitis C virus), MCV (Merkel cell virus), EBV (Ebstein Barr virus), and HPV (Human papillomavirus).

Other options:

Option A: Human papilloma virus types 16 and 18 cause cervical cancer due to mutations in the RAS gene.

Option B & C: Pox virus and HHV 7 are not oncogenic viruses.

questions.text: The clinical picture and a biopsy from the skin lesion of a patient are shown below. This condition is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical image shows diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface (erythroderma) and histopathology shows the presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cell layer (epidermotropism). This is suggestive of Sézary syndrome which is a disseminated and severe form of mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma).

Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CD4+ T-cells) that presents in the skin. It remains localized to the skin for many years, but it may eventually evolve into a systemic lymphoma.

The image of mycosis fungoides showing hallmark features - Sezary Lutzner cells showing epidermal infiltration (epidermotropism),

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic female patient presents with progressive skin lesions, as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows a central ulcer with raised borders and rolled-out edges (rodent ulcer) suggesting a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics. It affects the pilosebaceous skin.

Ultraviolet radiation exposure is the strongest predisposing factor. Other risk factors include exposure to arsenic, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and ionizing radiation. 

Basal cell carcinoma mainly affects elderly or middle-aged men with excessive skin exposure, commonly in the age group of 40–80 y and in white-skinned people.

Macroscopically, it is categorized as localized and generalized. Nodular, nodulocystic (nodular and nodulocystic together account for 90% of basal cell carcinoma), pigmented, and nevoid are the localized cancers, while superficial multifocal and superficial spreading, infiltrative, and cicatrizing are the generalized types. The nodular type is described as pearly waxy nodules at the margins. A central depression (umbilication) or ulceration and rolled-out edges are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma.

The below gross image shows pearly, rolled-out borders suggestive of basal cell carcinoma.

Sites near the eye, nose, and ear and of size >2 cm are considered to be high risk. Direct invasion at these sites can reach the cranium.

Management is by Mohs microscopic surgery. Non-surgical measures, such as the administration of topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod, are useful. Metastasis is extremely rare.

Other options:

Option A:  Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer. UV radiation exposure is the primary risk factor for SCC. Classically, it appears as a scaly or ulcerated papule or plaque that can bleed with minimal trauma, but the pain is rare. It can exhibit in situ (confined to the epidermis) or invasive subtypes. Wide surgical excision including subcutaneous fat is the treatment of choice for SCC.

Option C: Discoid lupus erythe­matosus (DLE): DLE is typically located on the nose, cheeks, ear lobe, and concha. It may involve lips, oral mucosa, nose, or eyelids. Initial lesions of DLE are dry red patches, which then progress to indurated red or hyperpigmented plaques with adherent scale. Follicular keratosis (plugs of keratin within hair follicles) is observed when the surface scales are removed (carpet-tack sign). Older lesions are hyperpigmented, especially on the plaque edges. There is scarring, which results in central loss of pigment, white patches, and skin atrophy. 

Option D: Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females. Melasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is most marked in brunettes. It occurs due to increased levels of estrogen and progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, and the chin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with history of sarcoidosis presents with skin lesions shown in the image below. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given condition is lupus pernio which is a cutaneous manifestation of sarcoidosis.

Lupus pernio is a chronic inflammatory skin lesion, which is diagnostic for a chronic form of sarcoidosis. It involves the bridge of the nose, the area beneath the eyes, and the cheeks and often is purple in color.

Other options:

Option A: Acne rosacea is a skin disorder with onset in middle‐aged adults (30–50 years old) and involves the convexities of the face.

Option C: Heliotrope rash presents as violaceous lesions around eyelids. It is seen in dermatomyositis.

Option D: Malar rash or butterfly rash is classically seen in SLE.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with skin lesions that are associated with loss of sensation. What is the most unstable form of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The image shows punched-out anesthetic lesions characteristic of the borderline spectrum of leprosy. The most unstable form of leprosy is the borderline-borderline type.

This type is rarely seen as it rapidly upgrades towards tuberculoid or downgrades towards lepromatous, based on the immune status of the individual. However, clinical features may lag behind the immunological and histological findings. This leads to numerous skin lesions and with features of both ends of the spectrum. 

Lepromatous and tuberculoid types are the most stable.

Classification systems of leprosy:

  • Ridley Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
  • Madrid classification:
    • Lepromatous (LL)
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline/dimorphous
    • Indeterminate (early unstable type)
  • Indian classification - includes categories under Madrid classification + pure neuritic type
  • WHO classification:

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He also gives the history of insect bite at the site of skin lesion. A blood test reveals a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins.  Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing eschar at the bite site along with a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins is suggestive of scrub typhus. It is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by O. tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 

The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

OX K is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy develops discolouration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object. This phenomenon is known as?
questions.solution:
Black dermographism is characterized by discoloration of the skin after pressure from a metallic object.

Dermographism refers to an exaggerated flare and weal response that occurs when skin is stroked or scratched. Dermographism is the most common form of chronic inducible urticaria or physical urticaria.

Other options:

  • White dermographism: This is due to capillary vasoconstriction following light stroking of the skin and occurs normally but is particularly pronounced in atopic eczema
  • Symptomatic dermographism: The triple response of local erythema due to capillary vasodilatation, followed by edema and a surrounding flare due to axon reflex‐induced dilatation of arterioles after stroking the skin accompanied by severe itching.
  • Urticaria pigmentosa: Presence of itchy pigmented macules on the trunk of a child due to numerous deposition of cutaneous mast cells.
